channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Gems, Warlords and Mercenaries: Russia’s Playbook in Central African Republic
item.description: After meddling in the 2016 American election, Russia is using similar tactics in the Central African Republic. But as it sows political chaos, this time it is also seeking diamonds.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: An artisanal diamond mine in the government-controlled area of Boda in the Central African Republic.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Status as Neutral Ground at Risk as China Asserts Power
item.description: The territory’s traditional role as a gateway is under assault from President Trump’s trade war and a crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police and protestors clash in Hong Kong on Sunday. The protests, and the police response, have raised doubts about China’s commitment to the territory’s semiautonomous status.

item.title: Thousands in Indonesia Protest Bills to Limit Rights and Ban Extramarital Sex
item.description: President Joko Widodo faces pressure to revoke a law curbing anti-graft efforts and to kill measures that would forbid abortion and sex outside marriage.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: A protest on Monday in Denpasar, on the resort island of Bali, against measures to ban sex outside of marriage and weaken Indonesia’s anti-graft agency.

item.title: France Honors Jacques Chirac With a Day of Mourning
item.description: World leaders gathered in Paris for a final tribute to the fondly remembered former French president, who died last week at age 86.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: The body of former President Jacques Chirac was carried out of the Invalides monument in Paris on Monday.

item.title: Xi Extols China’s ‘Red’ Heritage in a Land Haunted by Famine Under Mao
item.description: Seventy years after Mao founded the People’s Republic, Xi Jinping visited Xinyang to rekindle revolutionary traditions. Its survivors of mass starvation went unmentioned.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A farmer in Gaodadian Village in the Xinyang region of Henan Province. 60 years ago, over half of the villagers in Gaodadian starved to death as a result of Mao’s Great Leap forward.

item.title: Car Bombers in Somalia Hit U.S. and European Military Bases
item.description: The extremist group known as the Shabab claimed responsibility for an attack on an American base used to launch airstrikes against the group.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The scene of an attack on an Italian military convoy in Mogadishu on Monday.

item.title: China’s 70th Anniversary: Parades and Protests
item.description: As the Communist Party celebrates 70 years in power, protests in Hong Kong threaten to overshadow the festivities.
item.dc:creator: Russell Goldman
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Soldiers awaiting the announcement of the founding of the People’s Republic of China at Tiananmen Square on Oct. 1, 1949.

item.title: Riots Erupt at Greek Migrant Camp on Lesbos After Deadly Fire
item.description: The authorities said the situation had stabilized, but others saw a need for more urgent action at the chronically overcrowded facilities.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: Fleeing clashes with the police on the Greek island of Lesbos on Sunday.

item.title: Boris Johnson Still Basks in Favor of Hard-Line Tories, Who Forgive All for Brexit
item.description: In London, the British prime minister seems to be facing one crisis after another. But in Manchester, where his Conservative party is meeting, it’s another story altogether.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain arriving Sunday for the Conservative party conference in Manchester, England.

item.title: Both Afghan Candidates Claim the Lead Even Before Votes Are Tallied
item.description: The clashing claims by President Ashraf Ghani and rival Abdullah Abdullah could set up a political crisis from the vote.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Fahim Abed
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah, center, a main contender in the presidential election, claimed victory in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Sees Rising Threat in the West From Qaeda Branch in Syria
item.description: American counterterrorism officials are voicing alarm about a Qaeda affiliate in Syria that they say is plotting attacks from the country’s northwest.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescue crews searching the rubble of a building in April after an explosion in Idlib Province, Syria. The province contains a witch’s brew of extremist groups.

item.title: Top Bodyguard to 2 Saudi Kings Is Shot Dead
item.description: Gen. Abdulaziz al-Faghem, who oversaw protection for two Saudi kings, was shot and killed in what the Saudi news media called a personal dispute.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Gen. Abdulaziz al-Faghem, left, in 2015 with King Salman of Saudi Arabia, whom he often guarded. General al-Faghem also guarded the previous king.

item.title: Kurz Wins Austria Election. Will He Turn to Far Right or Greens to Govern?
item.description: Sebastian Kurz, who came in first in a snap election in Austria, has a choice: Partner again with the far-right party that collapsed his government or shift left?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Sebastian Kurz, who was Austria’s chancellor from late 2017 until May, speaking to the media after voting on Sunday.

item.title: As Deadly Floods Engulf Nepal Border, Anger Turns to India
item.description: Nepal said embankments built by India along a shared border made flooding worse in their country during the summer monsoon season, killing dozens.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Kai Schultz
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: People walking in the rain along an embankment built by India at the border it shares with Nepal.

item.title: Luxury Cars Seized From African Leader’s Son Are Auctioned in Geneva
item.description: Vehicles linked to an inquiry into graft in Equatorial Guinea yielded $27 million at auction.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra
item.media:description: Supercars from a collection owned by a son of Equatorial Guinea’s president were shown on Friday at an auction preview in the Swiss village of Cheserex.

item.title: Unveiling Monument to Migrants, Pope Francis Urges Compassion for Refugees
item.description: The pope unveiled the sculpture in St. Peter’s Square during a special Mass and portrayed migration as an opportunity to “promote the integral human development of all people.”
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis unveiled “Angels Unaware,” a sculpture by the Canadian artist Timothy Schmalz representing displaced people throughout history, on Sunday in St. Peter’s Square.

item.title: Revisiting Hitler, in a New Authoritarian Age
item.description: With nationalism and anti-Semitism on the rise around the world, two big new biographies look at the Nazi leader’s march to power.
item.dc:creator: Talya Zax
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Hitler outside party headquarters in 1931. The biographers Peter Longerich and Brendan Simms have new books about his rise to power.

item.title: U.S. Businesswoman Admitted Affair With Boris Johnson, U.K. Report Says
item.description: The woman, Jennifer Arcuri, reportedly told friends that she was having an affair with Mr. Johnson when he was mayor, deepening the scandal as he tries to navigate an impasse over Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, center, then the mayor of London, and Jennifer Arcuri, left, at a conference in the British capital in 2014.

item.title: Major Clashes Erupt in Hong Kong Ahead of China’s National Day
item.description: The demonstrations openly defy Beijing’s rule just two days before the central government celebrates 70 years of Communist rule.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Keith Bradsher and Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The riot police detaining a protester near the government’s offices.

item.title: Soweto, Once Unified Against Apartheid, Is Now Divided by Wealth
item.description: The township was once a symbol of united resistance to a racist regime in South Africa. Now it embodies the class divisions in the country’s black majority.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Agnes Sehole uses candles for light. “It’s getting worse,” said Ms. Sehole. “There’s nothing that I’ve experienced of the new South Africa.”

item.title: Haiti Gripped by Violent Protests Amid Calls for President’s Ouster
item.description: Streets, schools and banks were closed throughout the country, bringing the economy to a standstill. “President Jovenel Moise is not doing anything for us, just killing us,” said a protester.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed

item.title: Syria Demands Immediate Withdrawal of U.S. and Turkish Forces, Again
item.description: Syria’s foreign minister demanded both countries evacuate their forces from the war-ravaged country or face “countermeasures.” Syria has made such threats before without taking steps to enforce them.
item.dc:creator: Kelly Virella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Walid al-Moallem, Syria’s foreign minister, speaking on Saturday at the United Nations General Assembly, described Turkey and the United States as “arrogant.”

item.title: Tanks, Missiles and No Pigeons: China to Celebrate 70th Birthday of the People’s Republic
item.description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, will use a military parade commemorating the 70th anniversary of Communist rule to highlight his power in the face of rising challenges.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: Tourists on Friday in front of a large screen set up at Tiananmen Square in Beijing for the 70th National Day celebration.

item.title: Justin Trudeau, the Instagram Prime Minister, Struggles to Resonate With Young Voters
item.description: Mr. Trudeau came to power by galvanizing young supporters. Keeping them in his corner is critical as he seeks re-election.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ryan Remiorz/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau with young supporters during a campaign rally this week in Thunder Bay, Ontario.

item.title: Tens of Thousands Rally in Hong Kong Before China’s National Holiday
item.description: The police used water cannons and tear gas as protesters commemorated the fifth anniversary of the pro-democracy Umbrella Movement, days before a major anniversary in China.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Andrew Jacobs and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters gathering at Tamar Park in central Hong Kong on Saturday evening.

item.title: Dutch Railroad Reckons With Holocaust Shame, 70 Years Later
item.description: Even as the national railroad company in the Netherlands begins paying compensation to the relatives of those it transported to death camps, new details of its collaboration are emerging.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: A Father-Son Split on Hong Kong Protests Shows City’s Generational Divide
item.description: As China celebrates the 70th anniversary of Communist rule, a father who fled the country wonders if he made the right decision, and why his son is protesting.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kenny Wong regularly joins antigovernment protests in what he sees as a fight for his son’s future. His father objects.

item.title: Austria’s Kurz, Leading in Polls, Looks Open to Reunion With Far Right
item.description: Four months after scandal imploded Sebastian Kurz’s coalition, the wunderkind conservative looks set to win again in Sunday’s election. Will he embrace the far right a second time?
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Sebastian Kurz, the former chancellor, in Vienna on Friday at the final election rally before Austrians vote on Sunday.

item.title: Afghanistan Election Draws Low Turnout Amid Taliban Threats
item.description: With peace talks on hold, the Taliban have stepped up attacks, and Afghans fear that a bitterly contested presidential election could lead to political paralysis.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Fahim Abed and Fatima Faizi
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station in Dara, in the Panjshir valley of Afghanistan, attracted few voters. Turnout was low over all.

item.title: Prince Harry Retraces Princess Diana’s Steps in Angolan Minefield
item.description: What was a live minefield in 1997, when Princess Diana highlighted the dangers of the weapon to civilians, is now a busy suburban street.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Prince Harry visiting a partially cleared minefield in Angola on Friday. “With peace,” he said, “comes opportunity.”

item.title: Angry Protesters in Haiti Call for Resignation of President
item.description: Opponents of President Jovenel Moise say his allies embezzled billions from an aid program.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters demanding the resignation of President Jovenel Moise faced the police in Port-au-Prince.

item.title: U.S. Military Again Strikes ISIS in Southern Libya
item.description: The Pentagon carried out its third airstrike in a week against ISIS fighters in Libya amid signs the group was seeking to increase its recruiting.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Two Blows Are Dealt to Ukrainian Leader’s Clean-Government Image
item.description: In a setback for President Volodymyr Zelensky, international lenders criticized government corruption and left Kiev without a deal. A top aide also stepped down.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday.

item.title: Imran Khan Warns of Kashmir ‘Blood Bath’ in Emotional U.N. Speech
item.description: The Prime Minister castigated India’s Kashmir crackdown. Narendra Modi, his Indian counterpart, ignored Kashmir in his speech.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone and Kelly Virella
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Khan of Pakistan castigated his Indian counterpart, Narendra Modi, during a speech at the United Nations General Assembly on Friday.

item.title: Greenland Calls On Denmark to Help Fight Child Sexual Abuse
item.description: A former mayor of the community of Tasiilaq said, “I believe we are in a human, social and cultural death spiral if we don’t manage to stop the sexual abuse.”
item.dc:creator: Martin Selsoe Sorensen
item.media:description: The small, isolated community of Tasiilaq is confronting an epidemic of child sexual abuse.

item.title: Who’s the Obstacle to Talks? Iran and U.S. Point at Each Other
item.description: The contradictory narratives added a new twist to the frantic efforts to broker a meeting between President Trump and the Iranian leader, Hassan Rouhani.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman/The New York Times; Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran said Friday that President Trump had offered to lift sanctions in order to meet. Mr. Trump denied that account.

item.title: ‘The New Berlin Wall’: Why Ukraine Is Central to the Scandal
item.description: Caught between East and West, it is a place that attracts adventurers and carpetbaggers, who return home with “legacies, memories and skeletons for their closets.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Caught between the clashing geopolitical ambitions of Russia and the West, Ukraine has for years had to balance competing outside interests.

item.title: Oleg Sentsov: Russian by Blood and Language, Ukrainian in Spirit
item.description: Released from a Russian jail in the Arctic in a prisoner swap, the filmmaker vows to fight on against what he calls President Vladimir V. Putin’s “political necrophilia.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleg Sentsov was imprisoned in frigid camps north of the Arctic Circle, and a global campaign for his release made the filmmaker a powerful symbol of resistance to President Vladimir V. Putin’s vision of Russia.

item.title: ‘One Country, Two Nationalisms’: The Identity Crisis Behind Hong Kong’s Turmoil
item.description: How economic dislocation and immigration set the stage for wider backlash against Beijing’s overreach — and for emerging divisions within Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in support of detained protesters in Hong Kong on Friday.

item.title: In Egypt, Scattered Protests Break Out for Second Week
item.description: The protests against President el-Sisi’s authoritarian rule were smaller than last week’s, but given the risks of dissent in Egypt, they still represented a stunning challenge to his authority.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan
item.category: Egyptian Center for Economic and Social Rights

item.title: Kremlin Says It Hopes Putin’s Calls With Trump Won’t Be Made Public
item.description: The contents of conversations between the two leaders have been of intense interest and speculation given the evidence that Russia interfered in the 2016 U.S. election.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: President Trump with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a bilateral meeting at the G20 summit in Osaka, Japan, in June.

item.title: Trump and Boris Johnson: Populist Peas in a Pod? Not Really
item.description: Their fortunes may seem to be in sync like never before. But that masks important character differences that could shape far different outcomes.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain and President Trump at the United Nations, on Tuesday. They are not so alike as commonly supposed.

item.title: Brother of Qandeel Baloch, Pakistani Internet Star, Gets Life Term for Her Murder
item.description: The case had returned the spotlight to a rampant practice of “honor killings” in Pakistan. The assailants often go free because the victim’s family forgives the killer.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Waseem Ahmed Azeem, the brother of the social media celebrity Qandeel Baloch, in Multan, Pakistan, on Friday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Plans to Let More Foreign Tourists Have Visas
item.description: The notoriously repressive kingdom will announce a new program as it tries to diversify its economy away from dependence on oil.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tour guides at the ancient ruins of Mada’in Saleh, in northwestern Saudi Arabia.

item.title: In Hong Kong, Unity Between Peaceful and Radical Protesters. For Now.
item.description: Five years ago, protesters were critical of even breaking windows. Now, some are throwing firebombs.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Hong Kong on Sept 15.

item.title: Afghanistan Presidential Vote Presses On Despite Concerns About Legitimacy
item.description: Accusations of systemic fraud and fears of Taliban threats have compromised an election that is likely to have the fewest voters since the first presidential vote in 2004.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Fatima Faizi
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Ghani, center, at a rally this month in Kabul. Until the past couple weeks, presidential candidates had held few events outside the capital for fear of attacks by the Taliban.

item.title: British-Flagged Tanker Leaves Iran, Two Months After It Was Seized
item.description: The Stena Impero, which Iranian authorities impounded in July, was heading to Dubai, where crew members will undergo medical checks.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wolgelenter
item.media:credit: Nazanin Tabatabaee/West Asia News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: The British-flagged tanker Stena Impero off the coast of Iran in August.

item.title: Looming Presence in Drug Conspiracy Case: Honduras’s President
item.description: President Juan Orlando Hernández, who won’t be at his brother’s U.S. trial, has been accused of using trafficking to “help assert power and control in Honduras.”
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser and Elisabeth Malkin
item.media:description: President Juan Orlando Hernández of Honduras speaking at the United Nations. His brother, Juan Antonio Hernández, goes on trial next week in connection with a narcotics trafficking conspiracy.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Amazing Reversal: Election Loser to Presumptive Premier
item.description: A week after an election appeared to jeopardize his career, Prime Minister Netanyahu is tapped to assemble a government. Israelis are wondering how it happened.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was tapped to form a new government, just a week after an election that appeared to doom his career.

item.title: U.S. Concludes Syria Used Chemical Weapons in May Attack
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stopped short of threatening a military response against President Bashar al-Assad’s government for the chlorine-loaded rocket attack.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.media:description: “The United States will not allow these attacks to go unchallenged,” Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Thursday.

item.title: ‘How Did We Miss Him?’: Student Death Prompts Inquiries in New Zealand
item.description: The body of a male student was discovered Monday evening at a campus residence in Christchurch, reportedly weeks after his death.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Canterbury University in Christchurch, where a student’s body was found, possibly after eight weeks undetected, according to local news reports.

item.title: New U.S. Aid to Saudi Arabia Will Include 200 Troops
item.description: The small deployment of defensive military hardware is tepid in comparison to some of the remarks leveled by American officials after the Sept. 14 strikes on Saudi oil fields.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: American and Polish soldiers with a Patriot missile battery in 2015 in Poland. The Pentagon is sending a Patriot missile battery and 200 troops to Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Israeli Arab Faction Explains Why It Didn’t Back Netanyahu’s Rival
item.description: The leader of Balad, part of the Joint Arab List bloc in Israel’s Knesset, said the differences between Benjamin Netanyahu and Benny Gantz were minor.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: Balad party leader, Mtanes Shehadeh, with other Arab Joint List party leaders in Nazareth, earlier in September.

item.title: BBC Rebukes Anchor Who Criticized Trump ‘Go Back’ Tweet. Now, It’s Under Fire.
item.description: The reprimand of a morning anchor, Naga Munchetty, for her remarks about the American president and racism, outraged many.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:description: Naga Munchetty

item.title: Security Tightens Over Protests in Egypt
item.description: Several small anti-government protests broke out in Egypt, despite a pre-emptive crackdown in which nearly 2,000 Egyptians were arrested.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Egyptian Center for Economic and Social Rights
item.media:description: Police standing guard in Ramses Square in Cairo on Friday. Central Cairo was teeming with security forces and nearly empty of civilians.

item.title: Canada’s Green Party Doctors a Photo. Opponents Cry Hypocrisy
item.description: A photoshopped image of Canada’s Green Party leader that shows her holding a reusable cup has raised charges of hypocrisy.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Elizabeth May, the leader of Canada’s Green Party, holding what she said was a compostable disposable cup, left, and a photoshopped image showing her holding a reusable plastic cup.

item.title: Australia’s Most Populous State Decriminalizes Abortion
item.description: The measure, which was approved in New South Wales, home to Sydney, after days of debate, overturned a 119-year-old law.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Alex Greenwich, a New South Wales lawmaker who introduced a bill to decriminalize abortion in the state, after the measure was approved on Thursday.

item.title: Carrie Lam Comes Face to Face With Angry Hong Kong Residents at Town Hall
item.description: Mrs. Lam met with 150 people on Thursday inside a heavily guarded stadium. She said she wanted to heal divisions and hear “constructive suggestions.”
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hong Kong’s chief executive, Carrie Lam, center, at a town hall meeting on Thursday.

item.title: On Khashoggi Killing and Yemen, Saudis Cannot Avoid Fresh Scrutiny
item.description: Saudi Arabia failed to stop an inquiry on atrocities in Yemen, and a documentary quotes Prince Mohammed bin Salman saying he has “all the responsibility” for the death of Jamal Khashoggi.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
